properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow heavy at times tonight. Snow heavy at times continues through to early Friday morning. Additional snowfall of up to 5 cm is expected on Friday before the snow comes to an end Friday evening. Total snowfall accumulations of 10 to 15 cm are possible by Friday evening. The Friday morning commute will be affected. Adjust your driving based on the road conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, and possible ice pellets and freezing rain. Total snowfall: near 15 cm, and possibly more. Location: Iles-de-la-Madeleine. Time span: tonight through Saturday morning. Remarks: Periods of snow will continue tonight and Friday. The snow is expected to become mixed with ice pellets on Friday afternoon and possibly with freezing rain Friday evening, before the precipitation changes back to snow later on Friday night. At this time, forecast guidance indicates that the area of heaviest snowfall will remain just west of the Islands, but this could change if the track of the system bringing the snow shifts further to the east. Strong northeasterly winds on Friday afternoon and evening, followed by strong northwesterly winds early Saturday morning, will cause reduced visibility in snow and blowing snow. Snow is expected to taper off to flurries Saturday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-07T18:27:00-00:00

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extreme cold wind chills of minus 40 or below tonight. Extreme cold wind chill values of minus 40 or below are forecast to develop tonight and then continue into Friday morning. After moderating Friday afternoon, extreme cold wind chills are expected to redevelop Friday night into Saturday morning over portions of Northeastern Ontario. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A total of 30 to 50 centimetres of snow is expected through Friday evening. Snow will intensify this evening and persist through Friday. In addition, strong northeast winds will gust up to 60 kilometres per hour. These winds combined with snow will cause blowing snow over several areas of Southern and Central Quebec. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, ice pellets and possible freezing rain expected. Locations: central and southern New Brunswick. Time span: Ending early Saturday morning. Remarks: Periods of snow will become mixed with or change over to ice pellets overnight tonight or Friday morning. There is a risk of freezing rain on Friday. The precipitation will change back to snow Friday night and then end overnight. Additionally, strong northerly winds on Friday night into Saturday morning will likely cause reduced visibility in blowing snow. Freezing rain warnings are in effect for parts of southern New Brunswick and snowfall warnings are in effect for northern New Brunswick. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-07T18:26:05-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, ice pellets and freezing rain are expected, followed by large waves, pounding surf and elevated sea water levels. Total snowfall and ice pellets: 10 to 15 cm (late tonight through Friday). Total freezing rain amounts: 5 to 10 mm (Friday night). Wave heights: 6 to 8 metres, breaking upon approach to shore (Saturday). Locations: Channel-Port aux Basques to Connaigre. Remarks: Snow will begin overnight and change to ice pellets during the day on Friday. The ice pellets will change to freezing rain Friday evening, and then eventually change to a brief period of rain showers before ending overnight Friday night. Storm surge and minor coastal flooding is possible along shorelines exposed to the southwest, especially near the morning high tide on Saturday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-07T18:17:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-07T02:18:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3465819811.2020

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, followed by a prolonged period of ice pellets and then freezing rain is expected. Total snow and ice pellet amounts: 10 to 15 cm. Total freezing rain amounts: 5 to 10 mm except 15 to 25 mm along the southern shore. Time span: Friday morning until midnight Friday night. Locations: Metro St. John's and the eastern Avalon Peninsula. Remarks: Snow will continue tonight and then change to ice pellets Friday morning. The ice pellets will change to freezing rain later Friday morning along the southern shore, while further north (including the Metro St. John's area), the ice pellets are expected to be more prolonged before eventually changing to to freezing rain late Friday afternoon. The freezing rain will change to rain near midnight Friday night then taper off before dawn on Saturday. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Utility outages may occur. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-07T18:19:09-00:00

Area: St. John's and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant amounts of snow and ice pellets are expected, followed by freezing rain. Total snowfall and ice pellet amounts: near 15 cm. Locations: northwestern Avalon Peninsula. Time span: early Friday morning until late Friday afternoon. Remarks: Flurries will change to snow, at times heavy, early Friday morning. A transition to ice pellets will then slowly migrate northward over the region Friday morning and afternoon. Extreme northern areas will likely receive near 15 cm of snow before the transition. Further south, snowfall totals are expected to be lower, but will be followed by a prolonged period of ice pellets. The ice pellets will change to freezing rain Friday evening and eventually to rain later Friday night. A freezing rain warning may be required with subsequent forecasts. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-07T18:10:55-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A fast-moving deepening low pressure system is approaching the South Coast of B.C. Strong winds will affect coastal B.C. from midday Friday until Saturday morning. Western sections of Vancouver Island from Zeballos to Sooke are currently under a wind warning. The low is forecast to approach northern Vancouver Island Friday afternoon and then track across Vancouver Island in the evening; however the exact track and strength of the low will affect the areas that will require wind warnings. Ahead of the low, strong southeast winds up to 70 km/h can be expected over northern sections of east Vancouver Island and Sunshine Coast Friday afternoon. Strong southwest winds of 50 to 70 km/h will affect southern sections of Victoria near Juan de Fuca Strait, such as Esquimalt, downtown Victoria, the Southern Gulf Islands, southern sections of Metro Vancouver and western sections of Lower Fraser Valley late Friday afternoon. Behind the track of the low, strong northwest winds up to 70 km/h are expected to sweep through the Strait of Georgia and may affect western sections of Metro Vancouver near the Strait of Georgia. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-07T16:02:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-07T00:03:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2684195523.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, ice pellets and freezing precipitation are expected. Total snowfall and ice pellets: 10 to 15 cm. Total freezing precipitation amounts: 2 to 5 mm. Locations: Gander, Bonavista North, Terra Nova, Clarenville and the Bonavista Peninsula. Time span: Friday morning until overnight Friday night. Remarks: Light snow will begin overnight tonight or Friday morning, and then become heavy at times by late afternoon. The snow will change to ice pellets Friday evening and to freezing rain overnight for more eastern areas. The precipitation will end as rain showers or drizzle before dawn Saturday. The snowfall amounts will depend heavily on how quickly the transition to ice pellets happens. A slower changeover will mean higher amounts and warnings might be needed for some areas. Flurries and gusty winds will develop during the day on Saturday with an additional 5 cm of accumulation possible, along with areas of blowing snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowmelt and runoff are expected, followed by strong winds and falling temperatures. Maximum gusts: southwesterly 80 to 100 km/h. Remarks: After the freezing rain changes to rain Friday night, temperatures are expected to rise to near plus 8 by early Saturday morning, resulting in melting snow and runoff. Strong southwesterly winds will then develop on Saturday morning and continue into Saturday afternoon. Temperatures will fall back below freezing during the day, causing residual water to re-freeze. Surfaces may become slippery. The winds are expected to ease Saturday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Storm surge warning Warning of potential coastal flood conditions issued jointly by Fisheries and Oceans Canada (Science) and the Meteorological Service of Canada - region of Quebec, on the 2020-02-06. An intense low pressure system from the east of the United States will bring moderate/strong/strong to high/high winds over the regions specified below. The combination of these winds and the fact that we are currently in period of mid-amplitude tidal range could produce minor flooding along the coast near theses localities, on the dates and at the times specified (Eastern Standard Time). Quebec City: 2020-02-07, 03:30 PM to 06:30 PM. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant ice build-up due to freezing rain is expected or occurring. Freezing rain amounts: possibly more than to 20 mm over some inland areas, with lesser amounts over southwestern Nova Scotia and along the coast. Location: Nova Scotia. Time span: tonight and Friday morning, and continuing into Friday evening over some northern regions. Remarks: An area of freezing rain will continue to spread northeastward through the course of the night. In the southwest, freezing rain has begun to change to rain along parts of the coast, but will continue into the overnight hours further inland. The remainder of Nova Scotia will see a prolonged period of freezing rain, which will gradually transition to rain on Friday from south to north as temperatures rise above freezing. Some inland areas may receive total freezing rain accumulations of 20 mm or more from this event. In addition, higher than normal water levels are likely along the Atlantic coast near high tide on Friday evening. Later on Friday night, winds will diminish and shift to northwesterly as a cold front crossing the province brings snow flurries and a rapid drop to colder temperatures. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and extremely hazardous. Extended and widespread utility outages are possible. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-07T18:20:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-07T02:21:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1412200325.2020

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall with blowing snow is expected. Total snowfall amounts: 25 to 40 cm (western Newfoundland) and 15 to 25 cm (Great Northern Peninsula). Locations: western and northern Newfoundland. Time frame: Friday afternoon until noon Saturday. Remarks: Flurries tonight and Friday morning over western Newfoundland will give way to snow, at times heavy, Friday afternoon. The heavy snow will spread to the Great Northern Peninsula Friday evening. Strong northeasterly winds gusting to 60 km/h will cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow Friday night and Saturday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-07T18:14:33-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:

Time span: Friday afternoon until early Saturday morning, Remarks: Flurries tonight and Friday morning will give way to snow, at times heavy, Friday afternoon. The snow will mix with or change to ice pellets Friday evening before tapering off early Saturday morning. There is a risk of freezing rain overnight Friday night. Strong northeasterly winds gusting to 70 km/h will cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow, especially prior to the ice pellets. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Total rainfall: 20 to 40 mm, and possibly more in some locations. Locations: southwestern Nova Scotia. Time span: tonight until Friday evening. Remarks: Freezing rain has begun to change to rain along parts of the coast and is expected to change to rain further inland by Friday morning as temperatures rise above zero. Periods of rain will continue, heavy at times, until Friday evening. Total rainfall accumulations of 20 to 40 mm are forecast, with the highest amounts expected over Cape Sable Island and vicinity. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

Remarks: Light snow during the day on Friday will give way to snow, at times heavy, late in the day. properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Ice build-up due to freezing rain is expected or occurring. Freezing rain amounts: possibly as much as 5 to 10 mm. Location: Prince Edward Island. Time span: Friday afternoon into the evening. Remarks: Snow will persist through the night, then change over to ice pellets on Friday morning and then to a mix of freezing rain and ice pellets on Friday afternoon. Precipitation will change back to snow on Friday night. Over the northernmost region of Prince County, precipitation may remain as snow through much of the day on Friday, with total accumulations up to 15 cm possible by Saturday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Ice build-up may cause tree branches to break. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Total rainfall: 25 to 40 mm. Locations: southern coastal Avalon Peninsula. Time span: Friday morning until late overnight Friday night. Remarks: Snow will quickly change through ice pellets and freezing rain to rain over southernmost sections of the Avalon Peninsula on Friday morning. The rain will continue, heavy at times, through the day on Friday, and eventually spread inland and northward Friday night. The rain should end before dawn Saturday. In addition, after the short mild spell Friday night, temperatures will fall below freezing again during the day on Saturday. Surfaces may become slippery as residual water freezes. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A fast-moving low approaching Vancouver Island will bring southwest winds of 60 to 90 km/h to western sections of Vancouver Island on Friday afternoon, As the low crosses Vancouver Island, winds west of the island, will veer to northwest 60 to 90 km/h, Friday evening, Winds will ease on Saturday. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Significant ice build-up due to freezing rain is expected or occurring. Freezing rain amounts: 15 to 25 mm. Locations: southern Avalon Peninsula, excluding southernmost coastal areas. Time span: Friday morning until midnight Friday night. Remarks: Snow will continue tonight and then change to ice pellets Friday morning. Over southernmost coastal areas, a quick transition through freezing rain to rain is expected to occur Friday morning. Elsewhere, the transition will take much longer, resulting in a prolonged period of freezing rain. Precipitation is expected to change to rain over all areas by midnight Friday night and will taper off before dawn Saturday. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and extremely hazardous. properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. An approaching low pressure system will give snow to the southern highway passes tomorrow. Snow over the Coquihalla Summit will start tomorrow morning and then spread to Kootenay Pass tomorrow afternoon. The snow will intensify tomorrow night as the low nears. Total snow accumulations of 20 to 30 can be expected before the snow tapers off to a few flurries early Saturday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
